projectDesc.p: This text is prepared as part of the Literature in Context project, which provides an accessible, curated, edited, and marked-up selection of primary sources relevant to the study and the teaching of British and American literature of the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. This project is funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities and developed by faculty at The University of Virginia and Marymount University.

interpretation.p: Research informing these annotations draws on publicly-accessible resources, with links provided where possible. Annotations have also included common knowledge, defined as information that can be found in multiple reliable sources. If you notice an error in these annotations, please contact lic.open.anthology@gmail.com.

normalization.p: Original spelling and capitalization is retained, though the long s has been silently modernized and ligatured forms are not encoded.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenation has not been retained, except where necessary for the sense of the word.

segmentation.p: Page breaks have been retained. Catchwords, signatures, and running headers have not.

correction.p: Materials have been transcribed from and checked against first editions, where possible. See the Sources section.

lg.l: How weak a Star doth rule MankindOur sun compared to others in the universe is considered weak, and yet if it explodes mankind dies.,
Which owes its ruine to the same
Causes which Nature had design'd
To cherish and preserve the frame!

l.ref: As Commonwealths may be secure, And so our bodies turn traitorous
l.note: We don’t fear outside violence but fear what is in our bodies. Such as mental illness, disease, or aging.

lg.l: And no remote Invasion dread;
Yet may a sadder fall endure
From Traitors in their bosom bred:

l.ref: So while we feel no violence,
l.note: (DRAFT-I worry this is too interpretive)We are not privy to the knowledge of the world in that we can sense things for example a volcano erupting.

lg.l: And on our active Health do trust,
A secret handDeath or time.doth snatch us hence,
And tumbles us into the dustBiblical reference, we start as dust, and then return to dust..
Yet carelesly(DRAFT)As if we are untouchable by death.we run our race,
As if we could Death's summons wave;
And think not on the narrow space(DRAFT)The narrow space refers to the limited lifespan.
Between a Table and a GraveA table in which you theoretically enter the world on, and a grave in which you exit the world in..
But since we cannot Death reprieve,
Our Souls and Fame we ought to mind,
For they our Bodies will survive;
That goes beyond, this stays behind.
If I be sure my Soul is safe,
And that my Actions will provide
